en: The trees overhead made a great sound of letting down their dry rain. The girl stopped and looked as if she might pull back in surprise, but instead stood regarding Montag with eyes so dark and shining and alive, that he felt he had said something quite wonderful. But he knew his mouth had only moved to say hello, and then when she seemed hypnotized by the salamander on his arm and the phoenix-disc on his chest, he spoke again.

es_translation: The trees, above their heads, whispered as they released their dry rain. The girl stopped and gave the impression that she was going to step back, surprised; but instead, she stood looking at Montag with eyes so dark, bright, and alive that he felt he had said something truly wonderful. But he knew that his mouth had only moved to say goodbye, and when she seemed to be hypnotized by the salamander embroidered on his sleeve and the phoenix disc on his chest, he spoke again.

tr_translation: While the trees above their heads shed their dry leaves like rain, they made a great noise. The girl stopped and looked as if she was about to retreat, but instead, she watched him with dark, bright, and lively eyes. Montag felt as if he had said something wonderful to her. But he knew that he had only moved his mouth enough to say hello, and when the girl, who saw the salamander on his arm and the round phoenix buttons on his chest, seemed hypnotized, Montag spoke again.

vi_translation: The trees above rustled and poured down a rain of leaves. The girl stopped and looked as if she might step back in surprise, but she stood there looking at Montag with eyes so black, so bright, so alive that he felt he had just said something wonderful. But he knew his mouth had only just moved to say hello, and when she seemed mesmerized by the fire dragon on his arm and the phoenix disc on his chest, he spoke again.

en: As he stood there the sky over the house screamed. There was a tremendous ripping sound as if two giant hands had torn ten thousand miles of black linen down the seam. Montag was cut in half. He felt his chest chopped down and split apart. The jet-bombs going over, going over, going over, one two, one two, one two, six of them, nine of them, twelve of them, one and one and one and another and another and another, did all the screaming for him. He opened his own mouth and let their shriek come down and out between his bared teeth. The house shook. The flare went out in his hand. The moonstones vanished. He felt his hand plunge toward the telephone.

He opened his own mouth and let their shriek come down and out between his bared teeth. The house shook. The flare went out in his hand. The moonstones vanished. He felt his hand plunge toward the telephone.

es_translation: While he remained motionless, the sky that stretched over the house began to howl. A tearing sound occurred, as if two giant hands had torn twenty thousand kilometers of black fabric along the seam. Montag felt split in two. It seemed to him that his chest was sinking and tearing apart. The rocket bombs kept passing, passing, one, two, one two, six of them, nine of them, twelve of them, one and one and another and another launched their howls through him. Montag opened his mouth and let the scream penetrate and come back out between his bared teeth. The house trembled. The lighter went out in his hands. The two small moons disappeared. Montag felt his hand rushing towards the phone.

tr_translation: As Montag stood there, the sky was screaming over the house. It was as if two giant hands were tearing apart a black linen cloth thousands of miles long, making a tremendous sound as they ripped it. Montag felt as if he were being torn in two. He felt his chest being split and shattered. Jet bombers were passing overhead, passing, passing, one two, one two, one two, six of them, nine of them, twelve of them, one, one, one more, another, another one... They were screaming all the screams for him. He opened his mouth and waited for the screams to pass in and out between his exposed teeth. The house shook. The fire in his hand went out. The moonstones vanished. He felt his hand reaching for the phone.

vi_translation: As he stood there, the sky above the house screamed. There was a terrible ripping sound as if two giant hands had just torn apart ten thousand miles of black linen along the seam. Montag was split in half. He felt his chest being split and divided into two halves. Bombers flew over, flew over again, flew over again, one two, one two, one two, six planes, nine planes, twelve planes, one plane then one plane then one plane then another plane and another and another, all screaming in his place. He opened his mouth to let their shrill screams descend and burst out from his bared teeth. The house shook. The flame went out in his hand. The two moonstones disappeared. He felt his hand reaching for the telephone.

en: Montag sank down into a chair and looked at this woman. Her eyes were closed now, gently, and he put out his hand to feel the warmness of breath on his palm.

en: â€œNo.â€ Montag gazed beyond them to the wall with the typed lists of a million forbidden books. Their names leapt in fire, burning down the years under his axe and his hose which sprayed not water but kerosene. â€œNo.â€ But in his mind, a cool wind started up and blew out of the ventilator grille at home, softly, softly, chilling his face. And, again, he saw himself in a green park talking to an old man, a very old man, and the wind from the park was cold, too.

es_translation: â€”No. Montag looked toward the wall, beyond them, where there were the typewritten lists of a million banned books. Their names were consumed in the fire, destroying the years under his axe and his hose, which sprayed kerosene instead of water. â€”No. But, coming from the ventilation grilles of his house, a cool wind began to blow, gently chilling his face. And, once again, he found himself in the park talking to an old man, a very old man, and the wind in the park was also cold.

tr_translation: "No." Montag stared at the wall behind them, where there was a list of millions of banned books. Their names were thrown into the fire under the hose that sprayed kerosene instead of water and the axe. "No." But inside his head, from the grill of the fan at home, a cool breeze began to blow, gently hitting his face. He saw himself again, talking to an old man, a very old man, in a green park, with a cold wind blowing from the park.

vi_translation: "No." Montag looked over their heads towards the wall where a catalog of millions of banned books was typed and hung. Their names had been thrown into the fire, burning for many years under his axe and hose, a hose that didn't spray water but kerosene. "No." But in his mind, a cold breeze rose from the ventilation grill at home, gently making his face tingle. And, once again, he found himself in a green park talking to an old man, a very old man, and the wind blowing from the park was also cold.

en: Next thing they were up in musty blackness, swinging silver hatchets at doors that were, after all, unlocked, tumbling through like boys all rollick and shout. â€œHey! â€œ A fountain of books sprang down upon Montag as he climbed shuddering up the sheer stair-well. How inconvenient! Always before it had been like snuffing a candle. The police went first and adhesive-taped the victim's mouth and bandaged him off into their glittering beetle cars, so when you arrived you found an empty house. You weren't hurting anyone, you were hurting only things! And since things really couldn't be hurt, since things felt nothing, and things don't scream or whimper, as this woman might begin to scream and cry out, there was nothing to tease your conscience later. You were simply cleaning up. Janitorial work, essentially. Everything to its proper place. Quick with the kerosene! Who's got a match!

es_translation: Instantly, they began the ascent in the darkness, striking with their silver hatchets doors that, however, were not closed, stumbling over each other like children, shouting and making a commotion. â€”Hey! A cascade of books fell on Montag as he hesitantly ascended the steep staircase. What an inconvenience! Before, it had always been as simple as blowing out a candle. The Police would arrive first, gag and tie up the victim, and take them away in their gleaming vehicles, so that when the firefighters arrived, they would find the house empty. No one was harmed, only objects. And since objects couldn't suffer, since objects didn't feel anything or scream or moan, as that woman could start doing at any moment, there was no reason to feel a guilty conscience afterward. It was just a cleaning operation. Everything in its place. Quick with the kerosene! Who has a match?

tr_translation: Then they plunged into the moldy darkness, swinging their silver axes towards the doors that, despite everything, were not locked, shouting with joy like children. "Hey!" Montag climbed the stairs, shaking them upright, as books began to pour down like a fountain. What an inconvenient situation! At first, it was always like blowing out a candle. The police would go ahead, tape their victims' mouths, and then lock them up in their shiny, bug-like cars, so when you arrived, you would find an empty house. You wouldn't hurt anyone, you would only hurt objects. And since objects can't really be hurt, they don't feel anything and don't scream or complain, so there would be nothing to trouble your conscience later, unlike this woman who started screaming and shouting. You were just cleaning up. Janitor cleaning, actually. Everything in its place. Quick, bring the kerosene! Who has the matches?

vi_translation: In a flash, they charged into the musty darkness, swinging silver axes at doors that turned out to be unlocked, stumbling like children rolling around and shouting. "Hey!" A cascade of books fell on Montag as he shakily climbed the upright ladder. How inconvenient! This used to be just like snuffing out a candle. The police went in first, taping the victim's mouth shut and then dragging them to their shiny beetle-like cars, so when we arrived, all we found was an empty house. We don't hurt people, we only hurt things. And since things don't actually feel pain, since things don't have feelings, and things don't scream or moan, like this woman might soon scream or cry, there will be nothing to trouble our conscience later. We're just cleaning up. It's really just sanitation. Putting everything back in its place. Kerosene, quickly! Who's got a match!

en: Mildred stood over his bed, curiously. He felt her there, he saw her without opening his eyes, her hair burnt by chemicals to a brittle straw, her eyes with a kind of cataract unseen but suspect far behind the pupils, the reddened pouting lips, the body as thin as a praying mantis from dieting, and her flesh like white bacon. He could remember her no other way.

Montag felt her presence there, saw her without opening his eyes; her hair had been burnt by chemical treatments, turning into brittle strands like dry straw. vi_translation: Mildred stood next to his bed, leaning down, curious. He felt her presence there, he could see her even without opening his eyes, her hair burnt by chemicals into a stubbly mess, her eyes like cataracts far behind her pupils, not visible but vaguely perceivable, her lips a bright red pout, her body thin like a praying mantis from a vegetarian diet, and her flesh resembling white bacon. He could not remember her in any other way.

en: â€œYou're a hopeless romantic,â€ said Faber. â€œIt would be funny if it were not serious. It's not books you need, it's some of the things that once were in books. The same things could be in the `parlour families' today. The same infinite detail and awareness could be projected through the radios and televisors, but are not. No, no, it's not books at all you're looking for! Take it where you can find it, in old phonograph records, old motion pictures, and in old friends; look for it in nature and look for it in yourself. Books were only one type of receptacle where we stored a lot of things we were afraid we might forget. There is nothing magical in them at all. The magic is only in what books say, how they stitched the patches of the universe together into one garment for us. Of course you couldn't know this, of course you still can't understand what I mean when I say all this. You are intuitively right, that's what counts. Three things are missing.

Books were only one type of receptacle where we stored a lot of things we were afraid we might forget. There is nothing magical in them at all. The magic is only in what books say, how they stitched the patches of the universe together into one garment for us. Of course you couldn't know this, of course you still can't understand what I mean when I say all this. You are intuitively right, that's what counts. Three things are missing.
es: â€”Es usted un romÃ¡ntico sin esperanza â€”dijo Faberâ€”. ResultarÃ­a divertido si no fuese tan grave. BÃºsquelo donde pueda encontrarlo, en viejos discos, en viejas pelÃ­culas y en viejos amigos; bÃºsquelo en la Naturaleza y bÃºsquelo por sÃ­ mismo. Los libros sÃ³lo eran un tipo de receptÃ¡culo donde almacenÃ¡bamos una serie de cosas que temÃ­amos olvidar. No hay nada mÃ¡gico en ellos. es_translation: â€”You are a hopeless romantic â€”said Faberâ€”. It would be amusing if it weren't so serious. It's not books that you need, but some of the things that were once in books. The same infinite detail and the same teachings could be projected through radios and televisions, but they are not. No, no: it's not books that you are looking for. Seek it where you can find it, in old records, in old movies, and in old friends; seek it in Nature and seek it for yourself. Books were only a type of receptacle where we stored a series of things we were afraid we might forget. There is nothing magical about them. The magic is only in what the books say, in how they stitched the various aspects of the Universe together into a whole for us. Of course, you cannot know this, you still do not understand what I mean by my words. Intuitively, you are right, and that is what matters. Three things are missing.

tr_translation: â€œYou are a hopeless romantic,â€ said Faber, â€œif you weren't serious, it would be very funny. What you need are not books, but some things that were once inside books. The same things could be in today's 'living room families.' The same infinite detail and consciousness could be broadcast from radios and televisions, but they are not. No, no, it's not books that you are looking for. Take it wherever you find it, in old records, old films, and old friends; look for it in nature and look for it within yourself. Books are a kind of repository and we store in them things we are afraid we might forget. There is nothing magical in them. The magic is only in what the books say, how they stitch the patches of the universe together and present them to us like clothing. Of course, you can't know this, of course, you still can't understand what I mean when I say this. Intuitively, you are right, and that is what matters. Three things are missing.

vi_translation: "You are a hopeless romantic," Faber said. "If this weren't serious, it would be very funny. It's not that you need books, what you need are some things that used to be in books. The same things that could be in today's 'parlor families.' The same endless detail and endless awareness that could be projected through radio and television, but it hasn't been projected. No, no, what you're looking for is not books at all! Gather it wherever you can find it, in old records, old movies, and in old friends, find it in nature and find it in yourself. Books are just one type of container where we store a lot of things we are afraid we might forget. There's nothing magical in them at all. The magic is only in what books say, in how books stitch the patches of the universe together into one garment for us. Of course, you can't know this, of course, you still can't understand what I mean when I say this. Instinctively, you are right, that's what matters. There are three things you lack.

Heaven and earth. I hit the mark. Look at the miserable expression on your face. A few blades of grass and a crescent moon. Oh, nonsense. What could she possibly do with those things?"

en: Montag stood looking in now at this queer house, made strange by the hour of the night, by murmuring neighbour voices, by littered glass, and there on the floor, their covers torn off and spilled out like swan-feathers, the incredible books that looked so silly and really not worth bothering with, for these were nothing but black type and yellowed paper, and ravelled binding.

en: Montag took the four remaining books and hopped, jolted, hopped his way down the alley and suddenly fell as if his head had been cut off and only his body lay there. vi_translation: Montag picked up the remaining four books and hobbled, swayed, and limped along the alley, suddenly falling as if his head had been severed and only his body lay there. Something inside him had jerked him to a halt and knocked him down. He lay where he had fallen, sobbing quietly, his legs drawn up, his face pressed against the gravel.

en: Montag pulled back into the shadows. Directly ahead lay a gas station, a great chunk of porcelain snow shining there, and two silver beetles pulling in to fill up. Now he must be clean and presentable if he wished, to walk, not run, stroll calmly across that wide boulevard. It would give him an extra margin of safety if he washed up and combed his hair before he went on his way to get where . . . ?

If he wanted to walk, not run, calmly cross the wide avenue, he had to be clean and presentable. That would grant him an additional margin of safety. If he washed and combed his hair, it would provide him with extra security before setting out. Setting out!

vi_translation: Montag slipped into the darkness. Right in front of him was a gas station, a large snow-white porcelain-like block glowing there, and two silver beetle cars pulling in to refuel. Now he needed to look clean and respectable if he wanted to just walk, not run, calmly striding across that wide boulevard. He would be a bit safer if he bathed and groomed himself before setting out to... to where?

en: And here was the gas station, its attendants busy now with customers. Approaching from the rear, Montag entered the men's washroom. Through the aluminium wall he heard a radio voice saying, â€œWar has been declared.â€ The gas was being pumped outside. The men in the beetles were talking and the attendants were talking about the engines, the gas, the money owed. Montag stood trying to make himself feel the shock of the quiet statement from the radio, but nothing would happen. The war would have to wait for him to come to it in his personal file, an hour, two hours from now.

es_translation: And there was the service station, with its employees attending to the customers. Approaching from behind, Montag entered the men's restroom. Through the aluminum wall, he heard a broadcaster's voice saying, "War has been declared." They were pumping the fuel. The men, in the vehicles, talked, and the employees conversed about the engines, the fuel, the money they owed. Montag tried to feel impressed by the radio announcement, but nothing happened to him. As far as he was concerned, the war would have to wait until he was ready to admit it into his personal file, an hour, two hours later.

tr_translation: And the gas station was there, the employees were now attending to their customers. Approaching from behind, Montag entered the men's restroom. He heard the radio on the aluminum wall saying, "War has been declared." Outside, cars were being refueled, people in the beetles were talking among themselves, while the station employees were discussing engines, gasoline, and the money to be paid. Montag waited long enough to feel the shock caused by the simple announcement made by the radio, but nothing happened. War, from now on, had to wait for one or two hours for his personal file to be closed.

vi_translation: And here is the gas station, now the employees are busy with customers. Approaching from behind, Montag stepped into the men's restroom. Through the aluminum wall, he heard a voice on the radio saying, "War has been declared." Outside, people were pumping gas. The people sitting in the beetle cars were chatting while the employees were talking about engines, gas, and money still owed. Montag stood trying to make himself feel the shock from the quiet announcement on the radio, but nothing happened. The war would have to wait for him to come to it in his personal files, an hour, two hours later.

en: Three blocks away a few headlights glared. Montag drew a deep breath. His lungs were like burning brooms in his chest. His mouth was sucked dry from running. His throat tasted of bloody iron and there was rusted steel in his feet.

vi_translation: A few blocks away, several headlights flared up. Montag took a deep breath. His lungs felt like burning brooms in his chest. His mouth was dry from running. His throat tasted of iron, like blood, and there was a rusty steel sensation in his feet.

en: The beetle was rushing. The beetle was roaring. The beetle raised its speed. The beetle was whining. The beetle was in high thunder. The beetle came skimming. The beetle came in a single whistling trajectory, fired from an invisible rifle. It was up to 120 m.p.h. It was up to 130 at least. Montag clamped his jaws. The heat of the racing headlights burnt his cheeks, it seemed, and jittered his eye-lids and flushed the sour sweat out all over his body.

The heat of the racing headlights burnt his cheeks, it seemed, and jittered his eye-lids and flushed the sour sweat out all over his body.

es_translation: The vehicle was rushing. The vehicle was buzzing. The vehicle was accelerating. The vehicle was approaching swiftly. The vehicle traced a whistling trajectory, shot by an invisible rifle. It was going about two hundred kilometers per hour. It was going at least more than two hundred per hour. Montag clenched his jaws. The heat from the vehicle's headlights burned his cheeks, made him blink, and froze the sweat that was running down his face.

tr_translation: The bug was hurrying. The bug was roaring. The bug was increasing its speed. The bug was whizzing. The bug was roaring loudly. The bug was coming, skimming the surface. The bug was coming like a single whistling bullet fired from an invisible rifle. Its speed was 120 miles per hour, at least 130 miles. Montag clenched his teeth. The accelerating headlights seemed to burn his cheeks and made him blink nervously, causing his whole body to be drenched in sweat.

vi_translation: The beetle is rushing. The beetle is roaring. The beetle is accelerating. The beetle is howling. The beetle is thundering like a storm. The beetle is gliding swiftly. The beetle is coming in a single shrieking trajectory, shot out from an invisible gun. It has reached 120 miles per hour. It has reached at least 130 miles per hour. Montag gritted his teeth. The heat of the headlamps at full speed seemed to burn his cheeks, making his eyelids twitch and causing sour sweat to pour out all over his body.

en: He began to shuffle idiotically and talk to himself and then he broke and just ran. He put out his legs as far as they would go and down and then far out again and down and back and out and down and back. God ! God! He dropped a book, broke pace, almost turned, changed his mind, plunged on, yelling in concrete emptiness, the beetle scuttling after its running food, two hundred, one hundred feet away, ninety, eighty, seventy, Montag gasping, flailing his hands, legs up down out, up down out, closer, closer, hooting, calling, his eyes burnt white now as his head jerked about to confront the flashing glare, now the beetle was swallowed in its own light, now it was nothing but a torch hurtling upon him; all sound, all blare. Now-almost on top of him !

es_translation: He began to drag his feet stupidly, talking to himself. And, suddenly, he gave a start and began to run. He stretched his legs as much as he could, over and over again, over and over again. God, God! He dropped a book, interrupted his run, almost turned around, changed his mind, kept going, screaming in the cement void, while the vehicle seemed to be chasing him, sixty meters away, thirty, twenty-five, twenty; and Montag was panting, waving his hands, moving his legs, up and down, closer, sweating, screaming with burning eyes and his head turned to face the glare of the headlights. Then, the vehicle was swallowed by its own light, it was nothing more than a torch rushing towards him; all noise and glare. Suddenly, it almost ran him over!

tr_translation: Like a dazed person, he awkwardly advanced, talking to himself for a while, then suddenly started running. He stretched his legs as far as they could go, descended, then again as far as possible, descended again, forward again, descended, forward again. My God! My God! He dropped a book, slowed down, almost turned back, changed his mind, lunged forward. In the concrete solitude, the bug was roaring, coming quickly along the path he was running on. Two hundred, one hundred meters behind, ninety, eighty, seventy, Montag was out of breath, his hands flailing in the air, his legs moving up and down, forward, up and down, forward, closer, closer, the horn blaring, shouting, his eyes now burning from the whiteness and his head turning violently to escape the glaring light, now the bug was engulfed by its own light, now nothing but a torch reaching towards him; all sound, all loud sound, now â€“ almost right on top of him!

vi_translation: He started to trudge like a fool while talking to himself, then he suddenly ran. He stretched his legs as far as possible, then put his foot down, then stretched out again, put it down, pulled his leg back, then stretched out again, put it down, pulled back. Oh God! Oh God! He dropped a book, hesitated, almost turned around, then changed his mind, pushed forward, shouting loudly into the thick emptiness, the car sped after its fleeing prey, two hundred steps away, one hundred steps, ninety, eighty, seventy, Montag gasped for air, flailing his arms, lifting his legs up and down, stretching out, lifting up and down, stretching out, closer, closer still, yelling, calling, his eyes now blazing white as he turned sharply to face the blinding light, now the car was swallowed in its own light, now it was nothing but a torch hurtling towards him; all noise, all blinding light. Now it was... almost upon him!

en: But the falling made a difference. An instant before reaching him the wild beetle cut and swerved out. It was gone. Montag lay flat, his head down. Wisps of laughter trailed back to him with the blue exhaust from the beetle.
en_masked: But the falling made a difference. An instant before reaching him the wild beetle cut and swerved out. It was gone. [MASK] lay flat, his head down. Wisps of laughter trailed back to him with the blue exhaust from the beetle.

es_translation: But the fall saved him. A moment before reaching him, the swift vehicle swerved. It disappeared. Montag lay face down, with his head bowed. The echo of laughter reached him, along with the sound of the vehicle's exhaust.

vi_translation: But the fall made things different. In the blink of an eye before it reached him, the mad car swerved in another direction and sped away. Montag lay, face down. Loud laughter echoed back towards him along with the blue exhaust smoke of the car.

en: They would have killed me, thought Montag, swaying, the air still torn and stirring about him in dust, touching his bruised cheek. For no reason at all in the world they would have killed me.
en_masked: They would have killed me, thought [MASK], swaying, the air still torn and stirring about him in dust, touching his bruised cheek. For no reason at all in the world they would have killed me.

en: But Montag was gone, hidden in the safety of the dark alley for which he had set out on a long journey, an hour or was it a minute, ago? He stood shivering in the night, looking back out as the beetle ran by and skidded back to the centre of the avenue, whirling laughter in the air all about it, gone.

vi_translation: Montag approached the house from the back, crawling through the yellow daffodils, rose bushes, and clumps of grass soaked with the smell of night dew. He touched the screen door at the back of the house, found it open, slipped inside, crossed the porch, and listened intently.

en: And Montag was out the back door lightly, running with the half-empty valise. Behind him he heard the lawn-sprinkling system jump up, filling the dark air with rain that fell gently and then with a steady pour all about, washing on the sidewalks, and draining into the alley. He carried a few drops of this rain with him on his face. He thought he heard the old man call good-bye, but he-wasn't certain.

vi_translation: And Montag gently slipped out the back door again, running with the half-empty suitcase. Behind him, he heard the lawn sprinkler system turn on, filling the dark air with a light drizzle and then a steady downpour, washing the sidewalks clean and draining into the alley. He carried a few drops of this rain on his face. He thought he heard the old man calling goodbye to him, but he wasn't sure.

en: With an effort, Montag reminded himself again that this was no fictional episode to be watched on his run to the river; it was in actuality his own chess-game he was witnessing, move by move.

en: One of them had to stop burning. The sun wouldn't, certainly. So it looked as if it had to be Montag and the people he had worked with until a few short hours ago. Somewhere the saving and putting away had to begin again and someone had to do the saving and keeping, one way or another, in books, in records, in people's heads, any way at all so long as it was safe, free from moths, silver-fish, rust and dry-rot, and men with matches. The world was full of burning of all types and sizes. Now the guild of the asbestos-weaver must open shop very soon.
en_masked: One of them had to stop burning. The sun wouldn't, certainly. So it looked as if it had to be [MASK] and the people he had worked with until a few short hours ago. Somewhere the saving and putting away had to begin again and someone had to do the saving and keeping, one way or another, in books, in records, in people's heads, any way at all so long as it was safe, free from moths, silver-fish, rust and dry-rot, and men with matches. The world was full of burning of all types and sizes. Now the guild of the asbestos-weaver must open shop very soon.

es_translation: Someone would have to stop burning. The sun would not, of course. By all appearances, it would have to be Montag, as well as the people he had worked with until just a few hours ago. Somewhere, there would have to be a start to save and preserve things so that everything could have a new beginning, and someone would have to take care of it, in one way or another, in books, in records, in people's minds, in any way as long as it was safe, protected from moths, silverfish, rust, mold, and men with matches. The world was full of flames of all types and sizes. Now, the asbestos weavers' guild would have to open its establishment very soon.

tr_translation: One of them had to stop burning. Of course, the sun wouldn't stop; so it seemed that it had to be Montag and the colleagues he had worked with until a few hours ago. Somewhere, the work of rescue and preservation had to begin again. Someone, in some way; in the form of books; in the form of records; in people's minds; in whatever form; had to start the work of protecting and preserving from moths, bugs, decay, fungi, and people with matches. The world was full of burnings of every kind and size. The guild of asbestos weavers had to open their shutters very soon.

vi_translation: One of them must definitely stop burning. The sun certainly cannot stop burning. So it must be Montag and the people he worked with until a few hours ago. Somewhere, the act of preserving and hiding must be restarted, and someone must do that preserving, in some way or another, in books, on tapes, in human minds, any way that is safe, as long as it does not fear being gnawed, moth-eaten, rusted, or molded, and does not fear those who carry matches. The world is full of things to burn, of all kinds and sizes. Now the guild of asbestos weavers must quickly open their shop.

en: There was a silence gathered all about that fire and the silence was in the men's faces, and time was there, time enough to sit by this rusting track under the trees, and look at the world and turn it over with the eyes, as if it were held to the centre of the bonfire, a piece of steel these men were all shaping. It was not only the fire that was different. It was the silence. Montag moved toward this special silence that was concerned with all of the world.

It was not only the fire that was different. It was the silence. [MASK] moved toward this special silence that was concerned with all of the world.

vi_translation: There was a silence gathering around that fire and that silence lay on the faces of the men, and she had time, enough time to sit by this rusty rail under the trees, to sit and look at the world and ponder it with her eyes, as if it were hanging on the fire, a piece of steel that all those men were sharpening. en: Montag walked slowly toward the fire and the five old men sitting there dressed in dark blue denim pants and jackets and dark blue suits. He did not know what to say to them.

en: He watched the dark steaming mixture pour into a collapsible tin cup, which was handed him straight off. He sipped it gingerly and felt them looking at him with curiosity. His lips were scalded, but that was good. The faces around him were bearded, but the beards were clean, neat, and their hands were clean. They had stood up as if to welcome a guest, and now they sat down again. Montag sipped. â€œThanks,â€ he said. â€œThanks very much.â€

tr_translation: He looked at the dark mixture, steaming from the top, that was poured into a small foldable cup and handed to him, drank it slowly, and realized that they were watching him with interest. His lips were scalded, but the coffee was good. The faces around him were bearded, but the beards were clean, neat, and their hands were clean. They had stood up as if to greet a guest, but now they had sat down again. Montag took a sip, "Thank you," he said. "Thank you very much."

vi_translation: He watched the others pour that dark, steaming mixture into a collapsible tin cup and then hand it to him. He sipped the coffee cautiously and felt their curious eyes on him. His lips burned, but it was a pleasant sensation. The faces around him were all bearded, but the beards were clean and neat, and their hands were clean too. They had stood up as if to welcome a guest, and now they sat back down. Montag sipped the coffee. "Thank you," he said. "Thank you very much."

Many years ago, I hit an arsonist when he came to burn my library. Since then, I have been on the run. Do you want to join us, Montag?"

en: â€œListen,â€ said Granger, taking his arm, and walking with him, holding aside the bushes to let him pass. â€œWhen I was a boy my grandfather died, and he was a sculptor. He was also a very kind man who had a lot of love to give the world, and he helped clean up the slum in our town; and he made toys for us and he did a million things in his lifetime; he was always busy with his hands. And when he died, I suddenly realized I wasn't crying for him at all, but for the things he did. I cried because he would never do them again, he would never carve another piece of wood or help us raise doves and pigeons in the back yard or play the violin the way he did, or tell us jokes the way he did. He was part of us and when he died, all the actions stopped dead and there was no one to do them just the way he did. He was individual. He was an important man. I've never gotten over his death. Often I think, what wonderful carvings never came to birth because he died. How many jokes are missing from the world, and how many homing pigeons untouched by his hands. He shaped the world. He did things to the world. The world was bankrupted of ten million fine actions the night he passed on.â€

Often I think, what wonderful carvings never came to birth because he died. How many jokes are missing from the world, and how many homing pigeons untouched by his hands. He shaped the world. He did things to the world. The world was bankrupted of ten million fine actions the night he passed on.â€

es_translation: â€”Listen â€”said Granger, grabbing him by the arm and walking by his side, while pushing aside the bushes to let him passâ€”. When I was a child, my grandfather died. He was a sculptor. He was also a very good man, he had a lot of love to give to the world, and he helped eliminate misery in our city; and he built toys for us, and engaged in a thousand activities during his life; his hands were always busy. And when he died, I suddenly realized that I wasn't crying for him, but for the things he did. I cried because he would never do them again, he would never carve another piece of wood and he wouldn't help us raise pigeons in the yard or play the violin as he knew how to, nor would he tell us jokes. He was a part of us, and when he died all those activities stopped, and no one was able to do them like he did. He was an individualist. He was an important man. I have never gotten over his death. Often, I think about the wonderful carvings that never took shape because of his death. How many jokes the world is missing, and how many pigeons have not been touched by his hands. He shaped the world, he did things for its benefit. The night he passed away, the world suffered a loss of ten million good deeds.

tr_translation: â€œListen,â€ said Granger, holding his arm and parting the bushes with his hands so they could walk through together, â€œMy grandfather, who was a sculptor, died when I was a child. He was also a very good man with a lot of love to give, and he had greatly helped in cleaning up many slum areas in our city. He would also make us toys. He had done millions of things while he was alive. His hands were always busy making something. And when he died, I suddenly realized that I wasnâ€™t crying for him, but for the things he had done. I cried because he would never be able to do them again, he would never carve pieces of wood, help us raise doves and pigeons in the backyard, play the violin as he always did, and make jokes. He was a part of us, and when he died, all his actions stopped and died, never to be repeated again. He was an individual. He was an important man. I could never accept his death. I often thought about what wonderful carving masterpieces couldnâ€™t come into the world because he died, how many jokes the world missed out on, how many pet pigeons were deprived of his touch. He had shaped the world. He had done things to the world. The night he died, the world lost ten million beautiful things.â€

vi_translation: "Listen," Granger said, then took his hand, walked with him, parting the bushes to make way for him. "When I was little, my grandfather died, he was a sculptor. In his lifetime, he was also a very kind person, with a lot of love to give to the world, he helped people clean up the slums in our city; he made toys for us and throughout his life he made millions of things; he never rested. And when he died, I suddenly realized that I wasn't crying for him, but for the things he did. I cried because he would never do them again, he would never carve another piece of wood, nor help us raise pigeons in the backyard or play the violin as he used to, or tell us jokes as he used to. He was a part of us and when he died, all actions came to a halt and no one did those things the way he did anymore. He was very special, he was an important person. I never got over his death. I often think, how many wonderful engravings will never come to be because he died. How many jokes will be lost from this world, how many carrier pigeons will no longer be touched by his hands. He shaped this world. He did many things for this world. This world was robbed of ten million beautiful actions the night he passed away."

vi_translation: Granger raised his hand. "Once, fifty years ago, my grandfather showed me some films of V-2 rockets. Have you ever seen an atomic bomb mushroom cloud from two hundred miles up? It's just a pinhole, it's nothing. With wild nature all around it.

en: Later, the men around Montag could not say if they had really seen anything. Perhaps the merest flourish of light and motion in the sky. Perhaps the bombs were there, and the jets, ten miles, five miles, one mile up, for the merest instant, like grain thrown over the heavens by a great sowing hand, and the bombs drifting with dreadful swiftness, yet sudden slowness, down upon the morning city they had left behind. The bombardment was to all intents and purposes finished, once the jets had sighted their target, alerted their bombardiers at five thousand miles an hour; as quick as the whisper of a scythe the war was finished. Once the bomb-release was yanked it was over. Now, a full three seconds, all of the time in history, before the bombs struck, the enemy ships themselves were gone half around the visible world, like bullets in which a savage islander might not believe because they were invisible; yet the heart is suddenly shattered, the body falls in separate motions and the blood is astonished to be freed on the air; the brain squanders its few precious memories and, puzzled, dies.

El bombardeo habÃ­a terminado para todos los fines y propÃ³sitos, asÃ­ que los reactores hubieron localizado su objetivo, puesto sobre aviso a sus apuntadores a ocho mil kilÃ³metros por hora; tan fugaz como el susurro de una guadaÃ±a, la guerra habÃ­a terminado. Una vez soltadas las bombas, ya no hubo nada mÃ¡s. Luego, tres segundos completos, un plazo inmenso en la Historia, antes de que las bombas estallaran, las naves enemigas habÃ­an recorrido la mitad del firmamento visible, como balas en las que un salvaje quizÃ¡ no creyese, porque eran invisibles; sin embargo, el corazÃ³n es destrozado de repente, el cuerpo cae despedazado y la sangre se sorprende al verse libre en el aire; el cerebro desparrama sus preciosos recuerdos y muere.

es_translation: Subsequently, the men who were with Montag were not able to say if he had actually seen anything. Perhaps a faint glow and movement in the sky. Maybe the bombs were there, and the jets twenty kilometers, ten kilometers, two kilometers up in the sky for a brief moment, like grain thrown from above by the enormous hand of the sower, and the bombs fell with dreadful speed and yet with a sudden slowness, onto the city they had left behind. The bombing had ended for all intents and purposes, so the jets had located their target, alerted their pointers at eight thousand kilometers per hour; as fleeting as the whisper of a scythe, the war was over. Once the bombs were dropped, there was nothing more. Then, three whole seconds, an immense span in History, before the bombs exploded, the enemy ships had traversed half of the visible sky, like bullets in which a savage might not believe, because they were invisible; yet, the heart is suddenly shattered, the body falls torn apart, and the blood is surprised to find itself free in the air; the brain scatters its precious memories and dies.

tr_translation: Later, the men around Montag couldn't really say they had seen anything. Maybe, just the glimmer of light and the movement in the sky. Maybe, the bombs there, ten miles, five miles, one mile above from the jets in just a moment, like seeds scattered by a great hand sowing seeds, descending at tremendous speed but with sudden deceleration, onto the sleepy city they left behind... Once the jets saw their targets and alerted their bombers at five thousand miles per hour, the bombing was over with all its targets and purposes, and the war had ended as if with the whisper of a scythe. Once the trigger of the bomb was released, everything was over. Now, in all of history, in the three seconds before the bombs hit, the enemy ships had traversed half the circumference of the world, like bullets that a wild island native would not believe in because they were invisible; yet the heart has suddenly shattered, the body has been divided into separate movements, blood has been astonished enough to spurt into the air; the brain squanders a few precious memories and dies in bewilderment.

vi_translation: Later on, the people around Montag couldn't tell if they had really seen anything or not. Perhaps it was just a bit of light and fleeting movement across the sky. Maybe there were bombs there, planes, ten miles, five miles, one mile overhead, just for a moment, like seeds scattered by a giant hand across the skies, and so many bombs rushing through so terrifyingly fast, but then suddenly slowing down to fall on the morning city they had left behind. The bombing was almost over, once the planes had sighted the target, informing the bombers at a speed of five thousand miles per hour; as swift as the swish of a war scythe ending. Once the bomb bay doors opened, the war was over. Now, for a full three seconds, the entire time in history, before the bombs hit the target, the enemy ships had already gone halfway across the visible world, like bullets that a wild islander might not believe existed because they were invisible; yet the heart suddenly shattered into pieces, the body disintegrated into separate moving parts, and all the blood was astonished to find itself freed into the air; the brain scattered its few precious memories, and then, bewildered, died.

en: The men lay gasping like fish laid out on the grass. They held to the earth as children hold to familiar things, no matter how cold or dead, no matter what has happened or will happen, their fingers were clawed into the dirt, and they were all shouting to keep their eardrums from bursting, to keep their sanity from bursting, mouths open, Montag shouting with them, a protest against the wind that ripped their faces and tore at their lips, making their noses bleed.
en_masked: The men lay gasping like fish laid out on the grass. They held to the earth as children hold to familiar things, no matter how cold or dead, no matter what has happened or will happen, their fingers were clawed into the dirt, and they were all shouting to keep their eardrums from bursting, to keep their sanity from bursting, mouths open, [MASK] shouting with them, a protest against the wind that ripped their faces and tore at their lips, making their noses bleed.

es_translation: The men lay gasping like fish out of water. They clung to the ground like children cling to familiar objects, no matter how cold and dead they are, not caring about what has happened or what may happen; their fingers were sunk into the dust and they all screamed to avoid the rupture of their eardrums, to avoid the explosion of their reason, with their mouths open, and Montag screamed with them, a protest against the wind that wrinkled their faces, tore their lips, and made their noses bleed.

tr_translation: The men were breathing with difficulty, like fish left on the grass. They were holding onto the world, just like a child holds onto what they know, regardless of how cold or hot it is, without considering what has happened or what will happen, with their fingers clawed into the soil, all of them shouting to prevent their ears from bursting, to keep from losing their minds. Montag was also shouting with them, protesting the wind that tore at their faces, ripped their lips, and made their noses bleed.

vi_translation: The group of men lay panting heavily like fish laid out on the grass. They clung tightly to the ground like children clinging to familiar objects, regardless of how cold or lifeless those objects were, regardless of what had happened or what would happen, their fingers dug deep into the earth, and they all screamed to keep their eardrums from bursting, to keep their minds from bursting, mouths open, Montag screamed with them, a protest against the wind tearing at their faces and ripping their lips, making their noses bleed.

en: Silently, Granger arose, felt his arms, and legs, swearing, swearing incessantly under his breath, tears dripping from his face. He shuffled down to the river to look upstream.
en_masked: Silently, [MASK] arose, felt his arms, and legs, swearing, swearing incessantly under his breath, tears dripping from his face. He shuffled down to the river to look upstream.

vi_translation: Silently, Granger sat up, feeling his arms and legs, cursing, whispering curses continuously, tears dripping from his face. He limped down to the riverbank and looked upstream.

en: â€œNow, let's get on upstream,â€ said Granger. â€œAnd hold on to one thought: You're not important. You're not anything. Some day the load we're carrying with us may help someone. But even when we had the books on hand, a long time ago, we didn't use what we got out of them. We went right on insulting the dead. We went right on spitting in the graves of all the poor ones who died before us. We're going to meet a lot of lonely people in the next week and the next month and the next year. And when they ask us what we're doing, you can say, We're remembering. That's where we'll win out in the long run. And some day we'll remember so much that we'll build the biggest goddam steam-shovel in history and dig the biggest grave of all time and shove war in and cover it up. Come on now, we're going to go build a mirror-factory first and put out nothing but mirrors for the next year and take a long look in them.â€

es_translation: â€”Now, let's go upstream â€”said Georgeâ€”. And let's keep one thing in mind: we are not important. We are nothing. Someday, the load we carry with us may help someone. But even when we had the books in our hands, a long time ago, we did not use what we took from them. We continued undaunted, insulting the dead. We continued spitting on the graves of all the poor who had died before us. During the next week, the next month, and the next year, we are going to meet many lonely people. And when they ask us what we are doing, we can say: "We are remembering." That's where we will win in the long run. And, someday, we will remember so much that we will build the greatest mechanical shovel in history, with which we will dig the greatest grave of all time, where we will put war and bury it. Come on, now. First of all, we must build a mirror factory, and for the next year, we will only make mirrors and look at ourselves in them for a long time.

tr_translation: â€œLetâ€™s start walking against the current now,â€ said Granger. â€œDonâ€™t forget one thing. You are not important. You are nothing. One day, the burden we carry might help someone. But long ago, even when we had books in our hands, we didnâ€™t use what we learned from them. We kept cursing the dead. We kept spitting on the graves of the poor souls who died before us. In the coming week, the coming month, the coming year, we will meet many lonely people. When they ask us what we are doing, you can tell them that we remember. This is where we will profit in the long run. One day, we will remember so much that we will build the greatest steam shovel in history, dig the biggest grave of all time, push the war into it, and cover it up. Come now, letâ€™s go to establish a mirror factory first and spend the next year making nothing but mirrors and looking at them for a long time.â€

vi_translation: "Now we go against the current," Granger said. "And never let go of this thought: You are not important. You are nothing. One day the burden we carry might help someone. But even when we had books in our hands, long ago, we didn't use what we got from them. We just went on insulting the dead. We just went on spitting on the graves of all the poor souls who died before us. Next week, next month, next year we will meet many lonely people. And when they ask what we are doing, you can say: We are remembering. That is where, in the long run, we will win. And one day we will remember so much that we will build the biggest steam shovel in history, dig the biggest grave of all time, throw war into it and bury it. Now, first we will build a mirror factory so that next year we will produce nothing but mirrors and look at ourselves for a long time."
